content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several pieces of tissue, predominantly consisting of lymph nodes embedded in adipose tissue. There are at least three large, round structures that are clearly lymph nodes. These larger nodes exhibit significant architectural distortion with large, central, eosinophilic (pink) areas, which are highly suspicious for extensive, possibly necrotic, metastatic carcinoma. There is also a smaller, more uniformly basophilic (purple) and solid-appearing nodule, which is also likely a lymph node but appears different from the others.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my task is to evaluate every lymph node for the presence of metastasis. While several larger nodes are overtly suspicious for cancer, it's crucial to assess all nodes, including those that appear less involved or grossly normal. The green box is placed on a smaller, more solidly basophilic lymph node. I am zooming into this area to carefully examine its architecture. I need to determine if it is a benign reactive lymph node (with preserved sinuses and follicles) or if it contains subtle metastatic deposits, such as micrometastases or isolated tumor cells, which might be missed at low magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the interface between a lymph node (left) and surrounding perinodal adipose tissue (right). The lymph node tissue is densely populated with lymphocytes and shows evidence of lymphoid follicles, some with ill-defined germinal centers. This architecture is consistent with a reactive lymph node. I am carefully scanning the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma for any atypical epithelial cells or malignant glands. In this specific field, I do not see any evidence of metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this area is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
